documentation_title.question: what is a sale deed
documentation_title.answer:
üìÑ Sale Deed:

Definition: A Sale Deed is the main legal document that transfers ownership from seller to buyer once the sale is complete.

Purpose:‚Ä¢ Legal proof of property ownership transfer
‚Ä¢ Required for all property transactions
‚Ä¢ Must be registered with government

Key Elements:‚Ä¢ Buyer and seller details
‚Ä¢ Property description and boundaries
‚Ä¢ Sale consideration amount
‚Ä¢ Date of transfer
‚Ä¢ Signatures of both parties

Registration: Must be registered at Sub-Registrar's office within 4 months of execution.

documentation_title.question: what is title deed
documentation_title.answer:
üè† Title Deed:

Definition: It shows the seller's legal ownership and ability to transfer property.

Importance:‚Ä¢ Proves legal ownership
‚Ä¢ Essential for property transfer
‚Ä¢ Required for loans and registration

What to Check:‚Ä¢ Original document availability
‚Ä¢ Chain of ownership
‚Ä¢ No encumbrances or liens
‚Ä¢ Valid and current

Verification: Always verify with local municipal records and legal experts.

documentation_title.question: what is mother deed
documentation_title.answer:
üìú Mother Deed:

Definition: The oldest document tracing the property's ownership lineage, vital to establish chain of title.

Purpose:‚Ä¢ Establishes ownership history
‚Ä¢ Required for title verification
‚Ä¢ Essential for legal compliance

What to Check:‚Ä¢ Original document availability
‚Ä¢ Complete ownership chain
‚Ä¢ No missing links
‚Ä¢ Proper registration

Importance: Without mother deed, property title cannot be verified completely.

documentation_title.question: what is encumbrance certificate
documentation_title.answer:
üîí Encumbrance Certificate (EC):

Definition: An EC certifies that the property is free from any legal or monetary liabilities such as mortgages or dues.

Purpose:‚Ä¢ Proves property is free from encumbrances
‚Ä¢ Required for loans and registration
‚Ä¢ Essential for title verification

What it Shows:‚Ä¢ No outstanding mortgages
‚Ä¢ No pending legal cases
‚Ä¢ No unpaid taxes or dues
‚Ä¢ Clean title status

Validity: Usually valid for 6 months from issue date.

documentation_title.question: what is khata certificate
documentation_title.answer:
üìã Khata Certificate/Extract:

Definition: A local municipal record recognizing property's existence, required for paying property tax and registering property.

Purpose:‚Ä¢ Municipal recognition of property
‚Ä¢ Required for property tax payment
‚Ä¢ Essential for registration

What to Check:‚Ä¢ Property details accuracy
‚Ä¢ Owner name matching
‚Ä¢ Tax assessment details
‚Ä¢ No pending dues

Note: Khata is different from Khata certificate - both are needed for complete compliance.

processes_stages.question: what are the steps in buying property in india
processes_stages.answer:
üè† Steps in Buying Property in India:

Step 1: Research & Planning‚Ä¢ Determine budget and requirements
‚Ä¢ Research locations and property types
‚Ä¢ Check property prices and trends

Step 2: Site Visit & Selection‚Ä¢ Visit properties and projects
‚Ä¢ Compare different options
‚Ä¢ Check developer reputation

Step 3: Legal Verification‚Ä¢ Verify property documents
‚Ä¢ Check title and ownership
‚Ä¢ Verify approvals and NOCs

Step 4: Financial Planning‚Ä¢ Arrange down payment
‚Ä¢ Apply for home loan
‚Ä¢ Calculate total costs (including taxes)

Step 5: Agreement & Registration‚Ä¢ Sign agreement to sell
‚Ä¢ Pay stamp duty and registration
‚Ä¢ Register sale deed

Step 6: Possession‚Ä¢ Take property possession
‚Ä¢ Transfer utilities
‚Ä¢ Move in or rent out

Timeline: 3-6 months for complete process

processes_stages.question: what is due diligence in property purchase
processes_stages.answer:
üîç Due Diligence in Property Purchase:

Definition: Verifying property's legal status, checking title clearances, approvals, encumbrance, conversions, and liabilities.

Legal Checks:‚Ä¢ Title verification and ownership chain
‚Ä¢ Encumbrance certificate
‚Ä¢ Pending litigation status
‚Ä¢ Property approvals and NOCs

Physical Checks:‚Ä¢ Site inspection and boundaries
‚Ä¢ Construction quality and approvals
‚Ä¢ Infrastructure and connectivity
‚Ä¢ Neighborhood development

Financial Checks:‚Ä¢ Property valuation
‚Ä¢ Tax payment status
‚Ä¢ Outstanding dues
‚Ä¢ Market price analysis

Importance: Essential to avoid future legal and financial problems.

processes_stages.question: when should a buyer get noc
processes_stages.answer:
üìã When to Get NOC (No Objection Certificate):

Timing: From relevant authorities before property transfer

Required NOCs:‚Ä¢ RERA: For project compliance
‚Ä¢ Society/Builder: For existing property
‚Ä¢ Environmental: For large projects
‚Ä¢ Fire Department: For high-rise buildings
‚Ä¢ Municipal: For layout approvals

When to Apply:‚Ä¢ Before signing agreement
‚Ä¢ During due diligence phase
‚Ä¢ Before loan application
‚Ä¢ Before registration

Importance: NOCs ensure all approvals are in place and reduce legal risks.

processes_stages.question: how is stamp duty paid
processes_stages.answer:
üí≥ How is Stamp Duty Paid:

Payment Methods:‚Ä¢ Online: Through state government portals
‚Ä¢ Offline: At designated banks or offices
‚Ä¢ Demand Draft: In favor of government

Payment Process:‚Ä¢ Calculate stamp duty amount
‚Ä¢ Choose payment method
‚Ä¢ Pay before registration
‚Ä¢ Get payment receipt

Documents Required:‚Ä¢ Property details
‚Ä¢ Sale agreement
‚Ä¢ Buyer and seller details
‚Ä¢ Property valuation

Timing: Must be paid before Sale Deed registration

Note: Keep payment receipt for registration process.

processes_stages.question: what is property registration
processes_stages.answer:
üìù Property Registration:

Definition: Legal recording of property transfer at the Sub-Registrar's office; makes ownership official.

Process:‚Ä¢ Submit Sale Deed with stamp duty
‚Ä¢ Pay registration fee
‚Ä¢ Present buyer and seller
‚Ä¢ Get witnesses to sign
‚Ä¢ Receive registration receipt

Requirements:‚Ä¢ Original Sale Deed
‚Ä¢ Stamp duty payment proof
‚Ä¢ Identity proofs of parties
‚Ä¢ Two witnesses
‚Ä¢ Registration fee

Timeline: Usually completed same day

Importance: Without registration, property transfer is not legally valid.

fees_taxes_financials.question: what fees does a buyer pay in addition to property cost
fees_taxes_financials.answer:
üí∞ Fees Buyers Pay in Addition to Property Cost:

Government Charges:‚Ä¢ Stamp duty (5-8% of property value)
‚Ä¢ Registration fee (1% of property value)
‚Ä¢ Municipal charges and taxes

Legal & Professional:‚Ä¢ Legal fees for document verification
‚Ä¢ Notary charges
‚Ä¢ Property valuation fees

Financial Charges:‚Ä¢ Home loan processing fees
‚Ä¢ Loan insurance premium
‚Ä¢ Bank charges

Other Charges:‚Ä¢ Brokerage (1-2% of property value)
‚Ä¢ Maintenance deposits
‚Ä¢ Society membership fees
‚Ä¢ Utility connection charges

Total Additional Cost: Usually 8-12% of property value

fees_taxes_financials.question: what is stamp duty
fees_taxes_financials.answer:
üñãÔ∏è Stamp Duty:

Definition: A state-levied tax on property transactions, based on location and property value.

When Applicable:‚Ä¢ Property purchase
‚Ä¢ Property sale
‚Ä¢ Property transfer
‚Ä¢ Lease agreements

Rates (Varies by State):‚Ä¢ Maharashtra: 5-6% of property value
‚Ä¢ Delhi: 4-6% of property value
‚Ä¢ Karnataka: 5-6% of property value
‚Ä¢ Tamil Nadu: 7-8% of property value

Calculation: Stamp Duty = Property Value √ó State Rate

Example: For ‚Çπ50 lakh property in Maharashtra:
Stamp Duty = 50,00,000 √ó 0.06 = ‚Çπ3,00,000

Payment: Must be paid before property registration.

fees_taxes_financials.question: what is registration fee
fees_taxes_financials.answer:
üìù Registration Fee:

Definition: A fee (separate from stamp duty) for officially recording the Sale Deed, typically 1% of property value.

Purpose:‚Ä¢ Official recording of property transfer
‚Ä¢ Government documentation
‚Ä¢ Legal proof of ownership

Calculation: Usually 1% of property value

Payment: Paid along with stamp duty

Importance: Without registration, property transfer is not legally valid.

fees_taxes_financials.question: what are legal fees
fees_taxes_financials.answer:
‚öñÔ∏è Legal Fees:

Definition: Charges paid to lawyers/notaries for verifying documents and preparing Sale Deed.

Services Included:‚Ä¢ Document verification
‚Ä¢ Title search
‚Ä¢ Sale Deed preparation
‚Ä¢ Legal opinion
‚Ä¢ Registration assistance

Typical Charges:‚Ä¢ Document Verification: ‚Çπ5,000-15,000
‚Ä¢ Sale Deed Preparation: ‚Çπ10,000-25,000
‚Ä¢ Complete Legal Process: ‚Çπ20,000-50,000

Factors Affecting Cost:‚Ä¢ Property value
‚Ä¢ Complexity of documents
‚Ä¢ Lawyer's experience
‚Ä¢ Location

Importance: Essential for legal compliance and risk mitigation.

fees_taxes_financials.question: is brokerage charged to buyer or seller
fees_taxes_financials.answer:
ü§ù Brokerage Charges:

General Rule: Generally charged to the buyer (often 1-2%) but negotiable; varies with local custom.

Typical Arrangements:‚Ä¢ Buyer Pays: Most common scenario
‚Ä¢ Seller Pays: In some markets
‚Ä¢ Split Payment: Both parties share
‚Ä¢ Negotiated: Based on market conditions

Brokerage Rates:‚Ä¢ Residential: 1-2% of property value
‚Ä¢ Commercial: 2-3% of property value
‚Ä¢ Rental: 1 month rent

Factors Affecting:‚Ä¢ Property type and value
‚Ä¢ Market conditions
‚Ä¢ Broker's services
‚Ä¢ Negotiation skills

Note: Always clarify brokerage terms before engaging services.

legal_regulatory.question: what is rera
legal_regulatory.answer:
‚öñÔ∏è RERA (Real Estate Regulation and Development Act):

Definition: RERA is a law enacted by the Indian government to protect homebuyers and bring transparency to the real estate sector.

Key Features:‚Ä¢ Project Registration: All projects must be registered with RERA
‚Ä¢ Transparency: Developers must disclose project details, approvals, and timelines
‚Ä¢ Escrow Account: 70% of project funds must be in separate bank accounts
‚Ä¢ Timeline Compliance: Developers must complete projects on time
‚Ä¢ Compensation: Homebuyers can claim compensation for delays

Benefits for Buyers:‚Ä¢ Protection against project delays
‚Ä¢ Transparent project information
‚Ä¢ Legal recourse for grievances
‚Ä¢ Standardized sale agreements

RERA Website: Check your state's RERA website for project details.

legal_regulatory.question: what documents needed for home loan
legal_regulatory.answer:
üìã Documents Required for Home Loan:

Personal Documents:‚Ä¢ PAN Card
‚Ä¢ Aadhaar Card
‚Ä¢ Passport size photographs
‚Ä¢ Address proof (Utility bills, Rental agreement)

Income Documents:‚Ä¢ Salary slips (last 3 months)
‚Ä¢ Bank statements (last 6 months)
‚Ä¢ Form 16 or IT returns (last 2 years)
‚Ä¢ Employment certificate

Property Documents:‚Ä¢ Sale deed/Agreement to sell
‚Ä¢ Property tax receipts
‚Ä¢ NOC from society/builder
‚Ä¢ Approved building plan
‚Ä¢ Encumbrance certificate

Additional Documents:‚Ä¢ Down payment proof
‚Ä¢ Property insurance
‚Ä¢ Legal opinion report

Note: Requirements may vary between banks and loan types.

legal_regulatory.question: what is gst in real estate
legal_regulatory.answer:
üè¢ GST in Real Estate:

Definition: GST is a tax levied on construction and real estate services.

Applicability:‚Ä¢ Under-construction properties
‚Ä¢ Ready-to-move properties (if construction completed after July 2017)
‚Ä¢ Commercial properties

GST Rates:‚Ä¢ Affordable Housing: 1% (without ITC)
‚Ä¢ Regular Housing: 5% (without ITC)
‚Ä¢ Commercial Properties: 18%

What's Included:‚Ä¢ Construction costs
‚Ä¢ Development charges
‚Ä¢ Basic amenities

What's NOT Included:‚Ä¢ Land cost
‚Ä¢ Stamp duty
‚Ä¢ Registration charges

Note: Ready-to-move properties are generally GST-free.

processes.question: how to buy property in india
processes.answer:
üè† Complete Property Buying Process in India:

Step 1: Planning & Research‚Ä¢ Determine budget and requirements
‚Ä¢ Research locations and property types
‚Ä¢ Check property prices and trends

Step 2: Property Search‚Ä¢ Visit properties and projects
‚Ä¢ Compare different options
‚Ä¢ Check developer reputation

Step 3: Legal Verification‚Ä¢ Verify property documents
‚Ä¢ Check title and ownership
‚Ä¢ Verify approvals and NOCs

Step 4: Financial Planning‚Ä¢ Arrange down payment
‚Ä¢ Apply for home loan
‚Ä¢ Calculate total costs (including taxes)

Step 5: Negotiation & Agreement‚Ä¢ Negotiate price and terms
‚Ä¢ Sign agreement to sell
‚Ä¢ Pay booking amount

Step 6: Documentation & Registration‚Ä¢ Complete loan formalities
‚Ä¢ Pay stamp duty and registration
‚Ä¢ Register sale deed

Step 7: Possession‚Ä¢ Take property possession
‚Ä¢ Transfer utilities
‚Ä¢ Move in or rent out

Timeline: 3-6 months for complete process

processes.question: how to apply for home loan
processes.answer:
üè¶ Home Loan Application Process:

Step 1: Eligibility Check‚Ä¢ Age: 21-65 years
‚Ä¢ Income: Minimum ‚Çπ25,000 per month
‚Ä¢ Credit score: 750+ (preferred)
‚Ä¢ Employment: Minimum 2 years experience

Step 2: Choose Bank/NBFC‚Ä¢ Compare interest rates
‚Ä¢ Check processing fees
‚Ä¢ Compare loan terms
‚Ä¢ Read customer reviews

Step 3: Calculate Loan Amount‚Ä¢ Down payment: 20-30% of property value
‚Ä¢ Loan amount: 70-80% of property value
‚Ä¢ EMI calculation based on income

Step 4: Gather Documents‚Ä¢ Personal documents (PAN, Aadhaar)
‚Ä¢ Income documents (Salary slips, IT returns)
‚Ä¢ Property documents
‚Ä¢ Bank statements

Step 5: Apply Online/Offline‚Ä¢ Fill application form
‚Ä¢ Submit documents
‚Ä¢ Pay processing fee

Step 6: Verification & Approval‚Ä¢ Document verification
‚Ä¢ Property inspection
‚Ä¢ Credit appraisal
‚Ä¢ Loan sanction

Step 7: Disbursement‚Ä¢ Sign loan agreement
‚Ä¢ Pay down payment
‚Ä¢ Loan disbursement

Timeline: 15-30 days for approval

processes.question: how to check property documents
processes.answer:
üìã Property Document Verification Process:

Essential Documents to Check:

1. Title Documents:‚Ä¢ Sale Deed/Conveyance Deed
‚Ä¢ Mother Deed (original sale deed)
‚Ä¢ Partition Deed (if applicable)
‚Ä¢ Gift Deed (if applicable)

2. Land Records:‚Ä¢ 7/12 Extract (Maharashtra)
‚Ä¢ Patta (Tamil Nadu)
‚Ä¢ Khata (Karnataka)
‚Ä¢ Mutation records

3. Approvals & NOCs:‚Ä¢ Building approval plan
‚Ä¢ NOC from society/builder
‚Ä¢ Fire safety certificate
‚Ä¢ Environmental clearance

4. Tax Documents:‚Ä¢ Property tax receipts
‚Ä¢ Water tax receipts
‚Ä¢ Electricity bills
‚Ä¢ Maintenance receipts

Verification Steps:‚Ä¢ Visit local municipal office
‚Ä¢ Check with sub-registrar office
‚Ä¢ Verify with society/association
‚Ä¢ Consult legal expert

Red Flags:‚Ä¢ Missing original documents
‚Ä¢ Pending litigation
‚Ä¢ Multiple owners without consent
‚Ä¢ Encroachment issues

financing_loans.question: can buyers finance beyond stamp and registration via loan
financing_loans.answer:
üè¶ Financing Beyond Stamp and Registration:

General Rule: Most banks finance up to 80-90% of property cost; balance from buyer.

What's Financed:‚Ä¢ Property cost
‚Ä¢ Basic construction costs
‚Ä¢ Essential amenities

What's NOT Financed:‚Ä¢ Stamp duty
‚Ä¢ Registration fees
‚Ä¢ Legal charges
‚Ä¢ Brokerage
‚Ä¢ Maintenance deposits

Down Payment Requirements:‚Ä¢ Residential: 20-30% of property value
‚Ä¢ Commercial: 25-40% of property value

Alternative Options:‚Ä¢ Personal loans for additional costs
‚Ä¢ Gold loans
‚Ä¢ Liquidate investments
‚Ä¢ Family support

Note: Plan for 8-12% additional costs beyond property price.

financing_loans.question: what is loan to value ltv
financing_loans.answer:
üìä Loan-to-Value (LTV) Ratio:

Definition: LTV ratio indicates portion of property cost financed by lender (e.g., 80%).

Formula: LTV = (Loan Amount / Property Value) √ó 100

Example:‚Ä¢ Property Value: ‚Çπ50,00,000
‚Ä¢ Loan Amount: ‚Çπ40,00,000
‚Ä¢ LTV = (40,00,000 / 50,00,000) √ó 100 = 80%

Typical LTV Limits:‚Ä¢ Residential: 80-90%
‚Ä¢ Commercial: 70-80%
‚Ä¢ High-Value Properties: 60-75%

Factors Affecting LTV:‚Ä¢ Property type and location
‚Ä¢ Borrower's income and credit score
‚Ä¢ Market conditions
‚Ä¢ Bank's risk assessment

Importance: Higher LTV means lower down payment but higher risk.

financing_loans.question: what documents are needed for home loan
financing_loans.answer:
üìã Documents Required for Home Loan:

Personal Documents:‚Ä¢ PAN Card
‚Ä¢ Aadhaar Card
‚Ä¢ Passport size photographs
‚Ä¢ Address proof (Utility bills, Rental agreement)

Income Documents:‚Ä¢ Salary slips (last 3 months)
‚Ä¢ Bank statements (last 6 months)
‚Ä¢ Form 16 or IT returns (last 2 years)
‚Ä¢ Employment certificate

Property Documents:‚Ä¢ Sale deed/Agreement to sell
‚Ä¢ Property tax receipts
‚Ä¢ NOC from society/builder
‚Ä¢ Approved building plan
‚Ä¢ Encumbrance certificate

Additional Documents:‚Ä¢ Down payment proof
‚Ä¢ Property insurance
‚Ä¢ Legal opinion report

Note: Requirements may vary between banks and loan types.

financing_loans.question: can non residents buy property in india
financing_loans.answer:
üåç Non-Resident Property Purchase in India:

Eligible Categories:‚Ä¢ NRIs: Non-Resident Indians
‚Ä¢ PIOs: Persons of Indian Origin
‚Ä¢ OCIs: Overseas Citizens of India

Property Types Allowed:‚Ä¢ Residential properties
‚Ä¢ Commercial properties
‚Ä¢ Agricultural land (with RBI approval)

Restrictions:‚Ä¢ Cannot buy agricultural land without RBI approval
‚Ä¢ Cannot buy plantation property
‚Ä¢ Cannot buy farm house

Payment Methods:‚Ä¢ NRE/NRO account transfers
‚Ä¢ Foreign currency conversion
‚Ä¢ Gift from relatives in India

Documentation:‚Ä¢ Passport and visa copies
‚Ä¢ Overseas address proof
‚Ä¢ Income proof from abroad
‚Ä¢ PAN card

Note: Consult legal experts for compliance.

financing_loans.question: is home loan interest tax deductible
financing_loans.answer:
üí∞ Home Loan Tax Benefits:

Interest Deduction: Yes, under Section 24(b) for interest and Section 80C on principal (up to limits).

Section 24(b) - Interest Deduction:‚Ä¢ Self-Occupied: Up to ‚Çπ2 lakh per year
‚Ä¢ Let-Out: No limit on interest deduction
‚Ä¢ Under Construction: Interest deduction starts from construction completion

Section 80C - Principal Repayment:‚Ä¢ Up to ‚Çπ1.5 lakh per year
‚Ä¢ Includes stamp duty and registration
‚Ä¢ Available only for first-time buyers

Additional Benefits:‚Ä¢ Section 80EE: Additional ‚Çπ50,000 for affordable housing
‚Ä¢ Section 80EEA: Additional ‚Çπ1.5 lakh for affordable housing

Conditions:‚Ä¢ Property must be in India
‚Ä¢ Loan must be from approved financial institutions
‚Ä¢ Construction must be completed within 5 years

Note: Consult tax advisor for specific benefits.

investment.question: is real estate good investment
investment.answer:
üí∞ Real Estate as an Investment:

Pros:‚Ä¢ Tangible Asset: Physical property you can see and touch
‚Ä¢ Appreciation: Property values generally increase over time
‚Ä¢ Rental Income: Regular monthly income from tenants
‚Ä¢ Tax Benefits: Deductions on home loan interest and property tax
‚Ä¢ Hedge Against Inflation: Property values rise with inflation
‚Ä¢ Leverage: Can buy with 20-30% down payment

Cons:‚Ä¢ Illiquid: Takes time to sell
‚Ä¢ High Transaction Costs: Stamp duty, registration, brokerage
‚Ä¢ Maintenance: Regular repairs and upkeep required
‚Ä¢ Market Risk: Property values can decrease
‚Ä¢ Management: Finding tenants and managing property

Best Investment Scenarios:‚Ä¢ Long-term investment (5+ years)
‚Ä¢ High-growth locations
‚Ä¢ Good rental demand
‚Ä¢ Stable income source

Alternative Options:‚Ä¢ REITs (Real Estate Investment Trusts)
‚Ä¢ Real estate mutual funds
‚Ä¢ Property crowdfunding

investment.question: how to calculate rental yield
investment.answer:
üìä Rental Yield Calculation:

Definition: Rental yield is the annual rental income as a percentage of property value.

Formula: Rental Yield = (Annual Rental Income / Property Value) √ó 100

Example Calculation:
‚Ä¢ Property Value: ‚Çπ50,00,000
‚Ä¢ Monthly Rent: ‚Çπ15,000
‚Ä¢ Annual Rent: ‚Çπ15,000 √ó 12 = ‚Çπ1,80,000
‚Ä¢ Rental Yield: (1,80,000 / 50,00,000) √ó 100 = 3.6%

Types of Rental Yield:‚Ä¢ Gross Yield: Before expenses
‚Ä¢ Net Yield: After expenses

Expenses to Consider:‚Ä¢ Property tax
‚Ä¢ Maintenance charges
‚Ä¢ Insurance
‚Ä¢ Repairs
‚Ä¢ Vacancy periods

Good Rental Yield Range:‚Ä¢ Residential: 2-4% annually
‚Ä¢ Commercial: 6-10% annually
‚Ä¢ Retail: 8-12% annually

Factors Affecting Yield:‚Ä¢ Location and demand
‚Ä¢ Property type and condition
‚Ä¢ Market conditions
‚Ä¢ Property management

key_terminology.question: what is carpet area
key_terminology.answer:
üè† Carpet Area:

Definition: Carpet area is the actual usable area within the walls of your apartment/house where you can lay a carpet.

What's Included:‚Ä¢ Living room, bedrooms, kitchen, bathrooms
‚Ä¢ Internal walls and columns
‚Ä¢ Balcony area (50% of balcony)

What's NOT Included:‚Ä¢ External walls thickness
‚Ä¢ Common areas (lobby, stairs, lift)
‚Ä¢ Terrace, garden, parking

Formula: Carpet Area = Built-up Area - (Wall thickness + Common areas)

Example: If built-up area is 1000 sq ft, carpet area might be 800-850 sq ft.

key_terminology.question: what is built up area
key_terminology.answer:
üèóÔ∏è Built-up Area:

Definition: Built-up area includes carpet area plus the thickness of external walls, internal walls, and common areas.

What's Included:‚Ä¢ Carpet area (usable space)
‚Ä¢ External wall thickness
‚Ä¢ Internal wall thickness
‚Ä¢ Common areas (lobby, stairs, lift)
‚Ä¢ Balcony (100% of balcony)

Formula: Built-up Area = Carpet Area + Wall thickness + Common areas

Example: If carpet area is 800 sq ft, built-up area might be 1000 sq ft.

key_terminology.question: what is super built up area
key_terminology.answer:
üè¢ Super Built-up Area:

Definition: Super built-up area includes built-up area plus common facilities and amenities.

What's Included:‚Ä¢ Built-up area
‚Ä¢ Common facilities (gym, pool, garden)
‚Ä¢ Corridors and lobbies
‚Ä¢ Lift and staircases
‚Ä¢ Parking areas
‚Ä¢ Clubhouse and amenities

Formula: Super Built-up Area = Built-up Area + Common facilities + Amenities

Example: If built-up area is 1000 sq ft, super built-up might be 1200-1400 sq ft.

Note: This is what developers often quote as the total area.

key_terminology.question: what is bhk
key_terminology.answer:
üõèÔ∏è BHK (Bedroom, Hall, Kitchen):

Definition: BHK is a standard way to describe the layout of residential properties in India.

Components:‚Ä¢ B = Bedroom(s)
‚Ä¢ H = Hall (Living room)
‚Ä¢ K = Kitchen

Common BHK Types:‚Ä¢ 1 BHK: 1 Bedroom + 1 Hall + 1 Kitchen
‚Ä¢ 2 BHK: 2 Bedrooms + 1 Hall + 1 Kitchen
‚Ä¢ 3 BHK: 3 Bedrooms + 1 Hall + 1 Kitchen
‚Ä¢ 2.5 BHK: 2 Bedrooms + 1 Hall + 1 Kitchen + 1 Study/Pooja room

Example: 2 BHK means you get 2 bedrooms, 1 living room, and 1 kitchen.

key_terminology.question: what is roi in real estate
key_terminology.answer:
üí∞ ROI (Return on Investment):

Definition: ROI measures the profitability of your real estate investment.

Formula: ROI = ((Current Value - Purchase Price) / Purchase Price) √ó 100

Types of ROI:‚Ä¢ Rental ROI: Annual rental income / Property cost
‚Ä¢ Appreciation ROI: Increase in property value over time
‚Ä¢ Total ROI: Rental income + Appreciation

Example: If you bought a property for ‚Çπ50 lakhs and it's now worth ‚Çπ60 lakhs:
ROI = ((60 - 50) / 50) √ó 100 = 20%

Good ROI Range: 6-12% annually for rental properties.
